name: FOG CUTTER
description: Tiki historian Jeff Berry called this drink “the Long Island Iced Tea of exotic drinks.”
instructions: Shake with ice and pour unstrained into a chilled tiki mug. Float .5 oz. of Lustau Cream Sherry. Garnish with a mint sprig

name: FOREIGN LEGION
description: Jonathon Sabathe helped Greg perfect the proportions of this rich rum drink he served during a guest-bartending stint at PDT.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over an ice sphere into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with an orange twist

proportions.ingredient_name: Marie Brizard Dark Crème De Cacao

name: FRAMBOISE FIZZ
description: Michael Klein chose Framboise, a Belgian ale produced by combining fresh raspberries and young lambic, to complement two old friends: tequila and chocolate.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled egg coupe. Top with 2 oz. Oud Beersel Framboise. Garnish with three raspberries on a pick

proportions.ingredient_name: Marie Brizard White Crème De Cacao.

name: FRANKFORT ROSE
description: Originally served with W. L. Weller Bourbon from Frankfort, Kentucky, Artemio switched his whiskey of choice to Bernheim Wheat Whiskey from Bardstown, Kentucky.
instructions: Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled egg coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: FRENCH 75
description: Named after the French 75-millimeter gun, a revolutionary piece of artillery employed during World War I.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Top with 1 oz. Moët Imperial Champagne. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: FRENCH MAID
description: Barman Sam Ross created a similar drink made with bourbon dubbed the Kentucky Maid: consider this her spicy French sister.
instructions: (reserve one for garnish). 6-8 Mint Leaves (and one sprig for garnish). Add the cucumber, mint, and simple syrup to a mixing glass and muddle. Add everything else, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Garnish with a mint sprig poking through a cucumber wheel

name: FRESA VERDE
description: To accentuate the vegetal quality of the Tequila, I muddled green bell pepper in this pomegranate strawberry margarita.
instructions: Add the strawberries, green pepper slices, and molasses to a mixing glass and muddle. Add everything else, then shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a slice of strawberry

proportions.ingredient_name: Strawberries, A Slice Taken Out Of The Middle And Reserved For Garnish

name: FRISCO
description: A Derby cocktail without the bitters, this stiff, elegant drink is named after one of the most established cocktail communities in the world.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: GILCHRIST
description: Former flautist Daniel Eun named this drink after his old flute repairman, Bob Gilchrist. He used Scotch whisky to reflect his heritage and omitted sugar: like Hemingway, Bob was diabetic.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

proportions.ingredient_name: Compass Box Asyla Blended Scotch Whisky

name: GIMLET
description: The Gimlet may have been named after British Royal Navy Surgeon General Sir Thomas Gimlette, who took his scurvy inhibitor with a tot of gin.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lime wheel

name: GIN & TONIC
description: Quinine, an extract from cinchona bark, was prescribed in the 19th century as an anti-malarial throughout the British colonies. To make it more palatable, it was added to fortified wines and tonic water.
instructions: Add everything to a chilled Collins glass filled with ice and stir briefly. Garnish with a lime wedge

name: GIRL FROM JEREZ
description: Inspired by the smoothness of Stan Getz’s saxophone in “Girl from Ipanema,” I softened the citrus in this Brazilian cachaça-based Daiquiri with Pedro Ximénez from Jerez.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with grated nutmeg

name: GOLD COAST
description: I created this old-fashioned style cocktail after visiting the Bjäre Peninsula in southern Sweden, where the golden potatoes used to make Karlsson’s vodka are grown.
instructions: Add the dill and Flaggpunsch to a mixing glass and muddle. Add vodka and ice, then stir and fine-strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with two spritzes of Diluted Aftel Black Pepper Essence

name: GOLDEN STAR FIZZ
description: Inspired by the tree blossoms that fill the streets with their heady perfume in the spring, I combined Golden Star sparkling jasmine tea with a hint of absinthe to complement Christian Krogstad’s namesake aquavit.
instructions: Add the cucumber, dill, and juices to a mixing glass and muddle. Add the aquavit, then shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled, St. George Absinthe-rinsed fizz glass. Top with sparkling jasmine tea. Garnish with a slice of cucumber

proportions.ingredient_name: Golden Star Sparkling White Jasmine Tea

name: GOLD RUSH
description: I’ll never forget coming to Milk & Honey for the first time, in 2003, and being served this drink. It fundamentally changed the way I viewed cocktails.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain over a large cube into a chilled rocks glass. No garnish

name: GREAT PUMPKIN
description: Nothing sums up the thrill of fall in the Northeast better than Charles Schulz’s masterpiece, “It’s the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown.”
instructions: Add everything to a mixing glass and swirl to decarbonate beer. Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled fizz glass. Garnish with grated nutmeg

proportions.ingredient_name: Deep Mountain Grade B Maple Syrup

name: GREEN DEACON
description: This drink is based on the Rosy Deacon recipe in Jones’s Complete Bar Guide. One night, I served it to my friend J. C. Iglesias, who suggested adding Absinthe.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled, St. George Absinthe-rinsed coupe. No garnish

name: GREEN HARVEST
description: In viticultural terms, “green harvesting” is when you prune immature grape clusters to force the vine to concentrate flavor and ripeness in the remaining fruit.
instructions: Muddle the grapes. Add everything to a mixing glass, then stir with ice and fine-strain into a chilled fizz glass filled with ice. Garnish with three Concord grapes on a cocktail pick

name: GREENPOINT
description: Mickey used to stroll through Greenpoint on his days off. The route gave him the idea to create a variation on a well-known cocktail from Milk & Honey called the Red Hook.
instructions: Rye Whiskey. 1 oz. Punt e Mes. 1 barspoon Yellow Chartreuse. 1 dash of Angostura Bitters. Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: HANKY PANKY
description: Ada Coleman, the Savoy Hotel’s head bartender from 1903 to 1926, created this drink for actor Charles Hawtrey, who said “By Jove! That is the real hank-ypanky.”
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist

name: HARVEST MOON
description: This drink looks like the sky during the harvest moon—when the reddish-orange moon (the orange twist) rises after sunset.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist

name: HARVEST SLING
description: According to David Wondrich, slings became popular around the turn of the 19th century in America. Later, they took the form of mini punches, served with citrus and liqueurs like this drink.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Garnish with a cherry and orange flag

name: HEIRLOOM
description: Concord grapes reminded Johnny of the Catskills, which brought back memories of his mother’s roasted artichoke (thus the Cynar) and tomato pasta.
instructions: Add the grapes and Strega to a mixing glass and muddle. Add everything else, then shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with two spritzes of diluted Aftel Anise Hyssop Essence

name: HEMINGWAY DAIQUIRI
description: Cuban Bar La Florida’s famous Daiquiri #3, served without the sugar for diabetic author and barfly Ernest Hemingway.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lime wheel

name: HENRY HUDSON
description: To commemorate the 400th anniversary of Henry Hudson’s discovery of Manhattan, we created this genever-based punch spiked with Indonesian Arrack to give you a hint of the part of the world he never reached.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with grated nutmeg

name: HONEYMOON COCKTAIL
description: This cocktail has a spirituous backbone that is sure to cast a fog over the most amorous honeymoon.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: HOT BUTTERED PISCO
description: The longest drink recipe in the book, Kevin Diedrich’s toddy is an Irish Coffee–Hot Buttered Rum hybrid.
instructions: Add everything to a pre-warmed heatproof mug and stir until vanilla butter dissolves. Top with sweetened whipped cream. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg

name: HOTEL D’ALSACE
description: David Slape named this drink after the posh Parisian hotel where Irish scribe and spirits devotee Oscar Wilde spent his last years.
instructions: Add the Cointreau, Bénédictine, and bottom half of rosemary sprig to a mixing glass and muddle. Add Bushmills and ice, then stir and fine-strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with the tip of the rosemary sprig

proportions.ingredient_name: Sprig Rosemary (Half For Muddling, Half For Garnish)

name: HOTEL NACIONAL SPECIAL
description: Will P. Taylor, who created this drink at the Nacional bar in Cuba, was the Old Waldorf-Astoria’s last manager before Prohibition shuttered the bar.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lime wheel

name: IMPERIAL BLUEBERRY FIZZ
description: Crème Yvette’s affinity for blueberries gave me the idea of introducing the pair to a more aristocratic couple: champagne and cognac.
instructions: Add the blueberries and Crème Yvette to a mixing glass and muddle. Add the Cognac and ice, then shake and fine-strain into a chilled egg coupe. Top with 2.5 oz. Moët Imperial Champagne. Garnish with an edible orchid

name: IMPERIAL SILVER CORN FIZZ
description: Our beloved regular Wylie Dufresne, the chef and owner of WD 50, created the corn water, meant to complement the corn-based Tennessee Whisky.
instructions: Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled egg coupe. Top with 1 oz. Moët Imperial Champagne. No garnish

name: IMPROVED WHISKEY COCKTAIL
description: In Imbibe! David Wondrich traces the evolution of the plain whiskey cocktail to more evolved versions such as the Fancy Whiskey Cocktail in the 1862 edition and the Improved version above, which appeared 14 years later.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled, Vieux Pontarlier Absinthe–rinsed rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: JACK ROSE
description: One of the many hypotheses surrounding the name of this drink is that it is a corruption of Jacquemot, a pink rose with a similar hue to this drink.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish
source: —William Boothby, The World’s Drinks and How to Mix Them, 1908

name: JAPANESE COURAGE
description: Dutch Courage, a nickname given to genever in the 17th century by English soldiers who were impressed by how hard the Dutch fought after a dram, is the backbone of this winter warmer.
instructions: Heat the sake in a bain-marie (do not boil). Pour the sake and everything else into a pre-heated heatproof mug. Garnish with a lemon wheel studded with 6 cloves

name: JAPANESE COCKTAIL
description: Jerry Thomas is believed to have created this concoction in June 1860 for a delegation of Japanese dignitaries who were staying in the Metropolitan Hotel—right across the street from his bar at 622 Broadway.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: JIMMIE ROOSEVELT
description: According to Baker, “It was warmish, and being a sort of Nephew-in-Law of Paul Garrett, dean of all American Vintners, and present ‘father’ of Virginia Dare, we brought out two chilled bottles of Garrett Champagne, and created this one.”
instructions: Stir the cognac with ice and strain into a chilled egg coupe filled with three cracked ice cubes. Add a sugar cube soaked with Angostura Bitters and top with 2 oz. Möet Imperial Champagne. Float the Green Chartreuse over the surface of the drink. No garnish

proportions.ingredient_name: Demerara Sugar Cube Soaked In Angostura Bitters

name: JOHNNY APPLE COLLINS
description: An improved John Collins that alludes to Johnny Appleseed, dressed up with fancy English soda and German Apple Schnapps.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Top with 2 oz. Fever-Tree Bitter Lemon Soda. Garnish with a lemon twist

proportions.ingredient_name: The Bitter Truth Jerry Thomas Bitters

name: JUDGMENT DAY
description: Charles’s tribute to Macchu Pisco founder Melanie Asher, who bailed him out of jail in New Orleans, where he was detained with a friend for dropping a bottle of tequila in the Old Absinthe House.
instructions: Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled, Pernod Absinthe-rinsed egg coupe. Garnish with 2 spritzes of St. Elizabeth Allspice Dram

name: JUNIOR
description: David Wondrich unearthed this sophisticated sour collected by Broadway press agent Murdock Pemberton in a 1937 issue of Esquire.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: KANSAI KICK
description: Using the Cameron’s Kick cocktail as a template, John deBary substituted malt whiskey aged on Japan’s Kansai plain in place of its Celtic brethren, used lime in place of lemon juice, and added a little Madeira for complexity.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

proportions.ingredient_name: Yamazaki 12 Year Old Japanese Single Malt Whisky

name: KINA MIELE
description: Kina alludes to “quinquinas,” which employ quinine as the primary bittering agent. Miele is Italian for honey, the base of Nonino’s brilliant honey distillate.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a grapefruit twist

name: KING BEE
description: When I asked Nate why he wanted to call his cocktail the King Bee, he sent me the lyrics to Muddy Waters’s song “I’m a King Bee.”
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Float .5 oz. Lustau Palo Cortado Sherry over the surface of the drink. No garnish

name: KIN KAN
description: “Kin kan” is Japanese for kumquat, the small, aromatic citrus fruit that is cultivated throughout Southeast Asia from autumn until winter.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled, St. Germain Elderflower Liqueur-rinsed coupe. No garnish

name: KOYO
description: “Koyo,” Japanese for colorful leaves, refers to the period when the leaves turn red, orange, yellow, and brown.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled, St. Germain Elderflower Liqueur-rinsed coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: LACRIMOSA
description: This dark, brooding Negroni variation, whose name means “tears” in Latin, substitutes rye for gin, amaro for sweet vermouth, and Luxardo Bitter for Campari.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a flamed orange twist

name: LA FLORIDA COCKTAIL
description: The weekend before Tales of the Cocktail in 2009, Jack McGarry worked a shift at PDT and served this delicious Daiquiri variation.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lime wheel

name: LAKE GEORGE
description: Brian came up with this cocktail while vacationing along the sunny shores of Lake George.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

proportions.ingredient_name: Glenlivet 12 Year Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky

name: LA LOUCHE
description: “Louche” means “questionable, mischievous behavior.” Consider this cocktail as its inspiration.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: LA PERLA
description: Many mistake the title of this cocktail as a nod to the famous lingerie store. It’s actually named after renowned tequila guru Tomas Estes’s bar in London’s Covent Garden.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: LAST WORD
description: If it wasn’t for legendary barman Murray Stenson of Seattle’s Zig Zag Café, this drink might still be dwelling in obscurity.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: LAWN DART
description: To barman Sean Hoard, nothing signifies the arrival of summer like the smell of fresh-cut grass. This cocktail simultaneously mimics the aroma and suggests a use for the field.
instructions: Muddle the bell pepper and agave syrup. Add everything else, then shake with ice and finestrain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Garnish with an umbrella and a lime wheel

name: LEAPFROG
description: In The Ideal Bartender Tom Bullock lists a Leaping Frog cocktail prepared with Hungarian Apricot Brandy and lime juice. I built upon the foundation, adding gin, mint, and bitters.
instructions: Muddle the mint leaves with the simple syrup. Add everything else, then shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: LEFT HAND COCKTAIL
description: Sam Ross combined his favorite classics, Italy’s Negroni and America’s Manhattan, into one drink and named the result after Lefty, an Italian-American character from the movie Donnie Brasco.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with 3 brandied cherries on a pick

name: LEFT COAST
description: This Aviationinspired cocktail, made with products from two of my favorite West Coast distillers, recognizes the ascent of microdistilled spirits on America’s “left coast.”
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: LE PÈRE BIS
description: In 2006, Rob Cooper asked me to create a hot drink with St. Germain. To prove that the liqueur could tame one of the most powerful spirits, I mixed it with one of Islay’s legendary peat monsters.
instructions: Add everything to a pre-heated heatproof mug and stir. Garnish with a lemon wedge studded with three cloves

proportions.ingredient_name: Ardbeg 10 Year Old Single Malt Scotch Whisky

name: LION’S TOOTH
description: The English word “dandelion” is a corruption of the French “dent de lion,” lion’s tooth, named after the toothy shape of the leaf.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

proportions.ingredient_name: Dandelion Root Infused Rittenhouse Bonded Rye Whiskey

name: L.E.S. GLOBETROTTER
description: Renowned pastry chef Johnny Iuzzini created this twist on the Cock ‘N’ Bull Special from Ted Saucier’s Bottoms Up while tending bar at PDT.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over an ice sphere into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with an orange twist

name: LITTLE BIT COUNTRY
description: Elayne Werns grew up on the edge of a nature preserve and spent her summers at a dude ranch in the Adirondacks. She confessed that her soul is country, so she mixed this drink to heat it up in the wintertime.
instructions: Muddle the jalapeño with the maple syrup. Add everything else, then shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a flamed orange twist

proportions.ingredient_name: Deep Mountain Grade B Maple Syrup
¼ Inch Slice Jalapeño With A Few Seeds

name: LUAU
description: A variation upon the Luau Grog published in Jeff Berry’s Sippin’ Safari, Gerry created this cocktail for two of our regulars: Gina Haase and Jack Fetterman.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with pebble ice. Top with more pebble ice and garnish with an umbrella, a lime wheel, an orange slice, and two large straws

name: MAI-TAI
description: Tiki godfather Trader Vic claimed he first served this drink to friends visiting from Tahiti in 1944, who pronounced it “Maitai roa!”—“Very good!”
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with pebble ice. Garnish with a mint sprig

name: MAE WEST ROYAL DIAMOND FIZZ
description: Mae West loved champagne, so LeNell included it along with pomegranate (the fruit of Aphrodite), bourbon (her favorite spirit), and a natural aphrodisiac: goji berries.
instructions: Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled egg coupe rimmed with sugar, cayenne, and cocoa powder. Garnish with three whiskey-soaked goji berries on a pick

proportions.ingredient_name: Goji Berry Infused Four Roses Single Barrel Bourbon

name: MANHATTAN
description: Regardless of the cocktail’s exact origin, the popularity of Italian vermouth in the latter half of the 19th century made it inevitable that it would eventually end up in the Whiskey Cocktail.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with three brandied cherries on a pick

name: MARGARITA
description: Margarita is Spanish for “daisy,” a style of sour originally sweetened with curaçao.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice or a chilled coupe (optional salt rim). Garnish with a lime wheel
source: —Picador Cocktail listed in W. J. Tarling’s Café Royal Cocktail Book, 1937

name: MARINER
description: John bolstered the smoky quality of the Scotch by sweetening this cocktail with a syrup infused with black cardamom, a Southeast Asian spice that is traditionally dried over an open flame.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a lemon twist

proportions.ingredient_name: Compass Box Oak Cross Blended Malt Scotch Whisky

name: MARTINEZ
description: Thanks to the efforts of bartenders such as Scotland’s Adam Elmegirab, who reproduced Boker’s Bitters commercially, drinks such as the Martinez have returned to the limelight.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist

name: MARTINI
description: Over the last hundred years, the preparation and choice of garnish of this protean cocktail has been one of the most accurate methods to measure the palate of an era.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with three olives on a pick or a lemon twist

name: MARY PICKFORD
description: Eddie Woelke of Havana’s Jockey Club named this cocktail after pioneering silentfilm actress and producer Mary Pickford.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: MASATAKA SWIZZLE
description: Stanislav Vadrna introduced this cocktail, named after Nikka Whisky founder Masataka Taketsuru, at an event during Paris Whisky Live in September 2009.
instructions: Add everything to a chilled rocks glass, then fill with pebble ice. Swizzle, then top with more pebble ice. Garnish with 3 dashes Peychaud’s Bitters and a mint sprig

proportions.ingredient_name: Nikka Taketsuru 12 Year Old Japanese Malt Whisky

name: MASTER CLEANSE
description: This cocktail was inspired by Stanley Burroughs’s detox cocktail, composed of lemonade, maple syrup, and cayenne pepper.
instructions: Shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a thin slice of jalapeño

proportions.ingredient_name: Deep Mountain Grade B Maple Syrup

name: MAY DAISY
description: The first drink Phil ever featured on the menu at Flatiron Lounge was the Daisy May. He used the recipe as a template to come up with this, which we featured on our first friends-andfamily menu.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled white wine glass filled with ice. Garnish with a mint sprig

name: MAY DAY
description: Note: the title doesn’t refer to a pilot’s plea for help; she’s talking about May 1, when you kick back and start enjoying the summer.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Top with 2 oz. Moët Imperial Champagne. No garnish

name: MELON STAND
description: Danger named this drink after her Minnesota dream bar, Jane’s Sweet Melon Stand.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with pebble ice. Garnish with three watermelon balls on a pick

name: MEXICANO
description: The cucumber reinforces the vegetal notes of the earthy tequila, which stands in for sweet vermouth in this regal Americano variation.
instructions: Muddle the cucumber slices in a mixing glass. Add spirits and ice, then stir and fine-strain into a chilled coupe. Top with 2 oz. Moët Imperial Champagne. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: MEZCAL MULE
description: Passion fruit and cucumber brighten this earthy mule spiced with native Mexican chili.
instructions: Add the agave syrup and cucumber slices to a mixing glass and muddle. Add everything else, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with a piece of candied ginger, a slice of cucumber, and a pinch of ground chili

name: MIDNIGHT EXPRESS
description: Don and John developed this recipe with the help of Abraço owner and barista Jamie McCormick.
instructions: Build in a pre-heated heatproof mug. Garnish with freshly whipped cream and grated nutmeg

proportions.ingredient_name: Walnut Infused Hine V.S.O.P. Cognac (See Buona Notte Recipe)

name: MILK PUNCH
description: This delicious New Orleans brunch staple is rarely served on menus north of the Mason-Dixon Line.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with one large cube. Garnish with grated nutmeg

name: MINT APPLE CRISP
description: Loosely inspired by the Crisp cocktail in Applegreen’s Bar Book, this delicate saketini showcases the subtle green melon and mint notes of the sake.
instructions: Muddle the apple slices, mint leaves, and simple syrup. Add everything else and ice. Stir and fine-strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with three honeydew melon balls on a pick

proportions.ingredient_name: Heart Of The Hudson Apple Vodka
¼ Inch Slices Granny Smith Apple

name: MINT JULEP
description: The key to preparing a great mint julep is a proper julep cup (preferably silver), crushed ice, lively mint and the finest overproof bourbon you can afford to mix with.
instructions: Muddle the mint leaves and simple syrup in a chilled julep cup. Add the bourbon and top with pebble ice. Swizzle, then top with more pebble ice. Garnish with 3 mint sprigs

proportions.ingredient_name: Mint Leaves (Plus 3 Mint Sprigs For Garnish)

name: MOJITO
description: The Mojito became popular again in 2002 after Pierce Brosnan (playing James Bond, of course) ordered one in Die Another Day.
instructions: Add the simple syrup and mint leaves to a mixing glass and muddle. Add everything else, then shake and fine-strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with ice. Top with 1 oz. club soda and garnish with the mint sprig
source: —Listed as the Rum Mojo in Juan A. Lasa’s Libro de Cocktail, 1929

proportions.ingredient_name: Mint Leaves (Plus 1 Mint Sprig For Garnish)

name: MONTGOMERY SMITH
description: On a slow night, Nate’s coworker challenged him to invent a drink called the Montgomery Smith.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: MONKEY GLAND
description: In Cocktails: How to Mix Them (1922), Robert Vermeire attributes this unusual mix to Harry McElhone, when he was still working at Ciro’s Club, in London.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled, Vieux Pontarlier Absinthe-rinsed coupe. No garnish

name: MORANGO FIZZ
description: “Morango” means strawberry in Portuguese, the language of Brazil, where cachaça comes from.
instructions: Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled fizz glass. Top with 1 oz. club soda. No garnish

proportions.ingredient_name: Strawberry Infused Mãe De Ouro Cachaça

name: MOSCOW MULE
description: The Moscow Mule was created by Jack Morgan of the Cock ‘n’ Bull restaurant in Los Angeles and John G. Martin of Heublein, the company that distributed Smirnoff.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled mule cup filled with ice. Garnish with a lime wheel and candied ginger
source: —Lucius Beebe, The Stork Club Bar Book, 1946

name: MOUNT VERNON
description: This cocktail was inspired by George Washington, who operated one of the largest distilleries in the country, located on his personal estate, Mount Vernon.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with three brandied cherries on a pick

proportions.ingredient_name: Gran Duque D’alba Brandy De Jerez

name: MUM’S APPLE PIE
description: Originally called the Apple Crumble, Simon created this drink for Koba, in Brighton, England.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass filled with pebble ice. Garnish with an apple slice sprinkled with grated cinnamon and nutmeg

name: NAVY GROG
description: The term “grog” was supposedly coined by members of the British Royal Navy, who named their rum ration (prepared with a tot of water) after Admiral Edward “Old Grog” Vernon, so nicknamed because he wore a grogram coat.
instructions: Build in a chilled Collins glass, then fill with pebble ice. Swizzle, then top with more pebble ice. No garnish

name: NEGRONI
description: The combination of gin, sweet vermouth, and Campari showed up as the Camparinette and the Campari Cardinal in French and Spanish cocktail books such as Cien Cocktails and L’Heure du Cocktail before being recognized universally as the Negroni.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into chilled coupe or over ice in a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with an orange twist

name: NEW AMSTERDAM
description: Manhattan was first colonized by Dutch traders, who renamed the island and surrounding area New Amsterdam.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: NEWARK
description: By the time John and I came up with this Brooklyn variation, there were so many cocktails named after neighborhoods in Brooklyn, we claimed Newark, New Jersey.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: NEWFANGLED

description: The Triborough is a twist on the Remember the Maine cocktail that Nate added to the list of cocktails named after New York City.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with an orange twist

name: TRIDENT
description: In his Essential Bartender’s Guide, Robert Hess says this drink “reflects my penchant for slightly obscure products not normally found in bars.”
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: T & T
description: The name is short for tequila and tamarind, two of the primary forms of airconditioning where López grew up, in Mexico.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist

name: TUXEDO
description: The tuxedo’s roots can be traced back to the Tuxedo Park Club, in New York’s Ramapo Mountains, where the sporty look became all the rage.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled, Vieux Pontarlier Absinthe-rinsed coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist and a cherry

name: UP TO DATE
description: Ensslin calls for Sherry Wine in the recipe, leaving the style open for interpretation. While an Oloroso would work nicely, Manzanilla lends vibrant salinity and bracing acidity.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: VACCARI
description: This cocktail, named after the creator of Galliano, should be recommended to someone craving a spirituous drink on a hot summer day.
instructions: Box Asyla Blended Scotch Whisky. .75 oz. Dolin Dry Vermouth. .5 oz. Galliano L’Autentico. 1 dash The Bitter TruthGrapefruit Bitters. 1 dash The Bitter Truth Lemon Bitters. Stir with ice and strain over a large cube into a chilled rocks glass. Garnish with a grapefruit twist

name: VAUVERT SLIM
description: Vauvert was home to a Carthusian monastery where Francois Hannibal d’Estrees presented the monks with a manuscript containing a recipe for “elixir of long life” in 1605.
instructions: (reserve one for garnish). 1 Egg White. Muddle 6 mint leaves with the lime juice. Add everything else, then dry-shake. Shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled, Laphroaig 10-Year-Old Single Malt Scotch-rinsed egg coupe. Garnish with a mint leaf

name: VELVET CLUB
description: Jane spiked L. V. Battersby’s Velvet Glove cocktail, from the Café Royal Cocktail Book (1937), with a splash of PDT’s “club” soda: Moët Imperial Champagne.
instructions: Crème de Cacao. Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Top with 1 oz. Moët Imperial Champagne. No garnish

name: VESPER
description: This Martini hybrid, named after Bond’s love interest in Casino Royale, is largely culpable for a generation of imbibers thinking that spirituous drinks should be shaken, not stirred.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: VIEUX MOT
description: The release of St. Germain Elderflower Liqueur in the early half of 2007 was followed by a frenzy of new cocktails employing it all over the country.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: VIEUX CARRÉ
description: According to Arthur, “This is the cocktail that Walter Bergeron, head bartender of the Hotel Monteleone cocktail lounge, takes pride in mixing.”
instructions: Stir with ice and strain over one large cube into a chilled rocks glass. No garnish
source: —Stanley Clisby Arthur, Famous New Orleans Drinks, 1937

name: WARD EIGHT
description: Whether or not the Ward 8 was created at the Locke-Ober Café in Boston’s eighth ward to celebrate the victory of Democrat Martin Lomasney in 1896 or not, politics have always been part of cocktail culture.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish
source: —The Cocktail Book: A Sideboard Manual for Gentleman, 1913

name: WATER LILY
description: This drink was served to a dear friend of Richard’s whose middle name is “Lily.”
instructions: Crème de Violette. .75 oz. Cointreau. .75 oz. Lemon Juice. Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist

name: WEESKI
description: David wanted to make Manhattans, but was out of rye, so he grabbed a bottle of Jameson’s 12-year-old and reached for Lillet Blanc instead of sweet vermouth.
instructions: Irish Whiskey. .75 oz. Lillet Blanc. .5 oz. Cointreau. 2 dashes House Orange Bitters. Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with an orange twist

name: WELLINGTON FIZZ
description: Named after a coastal town on New Zealand’s northern island, this fizz marries the classic American Ramos Gin Fizz with a “kiwi” delicacy: passion fruit pavlova.
instructions: Dry shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled Collins glass. Top with 1 oz. club soda and garnish with 3 spritzes of diluted Aftel Bergamot Essence

name: WHISKEY SMASH
description: According to Dale, “I created this drink at the Rainbow Room, where I served it to folks who proclaimed they would never drink whiskey.”
instructions: Muddle the lemon wedges, mint leaves, and simple syrup. Add the rye, then shake with ice and fine-strain into a chilled rocks glass filled with ice. Garnish with a mint sprig

proportions.ingredient_name: Mint Leaves (Plus 1 Mint Sprig For Garnish)

name: WHITE BIRCH FIZZ
description: John created this drink at his childhood home on White Birch Lane for his mother who loves gin.
instructions: Dry-shake, then shake with ice. Strain into a chilled Collins glass. Top with 2 oz. club soda and garnish with a spritz of Suze

name: WHITE LADY
description: You can still order McElhone’s creation at Harry’s New York Bar in Paris from one of the bar’s old-school, whitecoated barmen.
instructions: Dry-shake, then shake with ice and strain into a chilled egg coupe. No garnish

name: WHITE NEGRONI
description: Wayne Collins created this aperitif for Nick Blacknell, who brought him a bottle of Suze to prepare drinks with before a dinner in Bordeaux.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: WIDOW’S KISS
description: George Kappeler penned Modern American Drinks while serving as head bartender at the Holland House, one of the finest hotels in New York City at that time.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. No garnish

name: WITCH’S KISS
description: This tequilabased ode to Kappeler’s Widow’s Kiss relies on saffronhued Strega in place of Yellow Chartreuse and apple butter in place of Bénédictine.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: WOOLWORTH
description: This drink is named after the Woolworth Building, once the tallest building in New York City.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled coupe. Garnish with a lemon twist

name: WRONG AISLE
description: Fruit vinegars or shrubbs, as they were called a century ago, work just as well in cocktails as they do in food preparation.
instructions: Stir with ice and strain into a chilled, St. Germain-Elderflower Liqueur rinsed coupe. Garnish with an apple fan dusted with nutmeg

Fee Brothers Whiskey Barrel Aged Bitters

name: ZOMBIE PUNCH
description: Tiki bar owners like Donn Beach went through a lot of trouble to keep their recipes a secret: only the most trusted staff members knew the full recipes, which were batched secretly and given to the bartenders on the front line to mix out of numbered bottles.
instructions: Shake with ice and strain into a chilled tiki mug filled with pebble ice. Garnish with a mint sprig
